text: While negative campaigning can potentially highlight weaknesses in an opponent's platform, it often leads to a more polarized and hostile political climate. It can shift the focus away from important policy discussions and instead promote mudslinging and personal attacks. Positive campaigning that emphasizes candidates' own qualifications and plans can still provide voters with the necessary information to make informed choices without resorting to negativity.

I believe that prioritizing human rights globally may not always lead to a better future for all. In some cases, prioritizing human rights above all else can lead to interference in the internal affairs of sovereign nations, causing political instability and conflict. This interference can sometimes do more harm than good, disrupting delicate balances and exacerbating existing tensions. It's essential to consider the complexities of each situation and the potential unintended consequences of imposing a one-size-fits-all approach to human rights worldwide.

Thank you, sir. Just to finish briefly, I started to say that for the last eight years Ive been on the National Security Council. Last week I broke up — I suspended campaigning for two days, or parts of two days, to go back and participate in the meetings that charted the Presidents summit meeting that he just returned from earlier today. And our team of — our countrys team over there did a great job. Its a difficult situation. The United States has to be strong in order to make sure that we can help promote peace and security and stability. And that means keeping our military strong. Now, I said earlier that we are the strongest military, but we need to continue improving readiness and making sure that our military personnel are adequately paid and that the combination of their pay and their benefits and their retirement as veterans is comparable to the stiff competition thats coming in this strong economy from the private sector. And I have supported the largest pay raise in many a year, and I support another one now. I also support modernization of our strategic and tactical weaponry. The governor has proposed skipping a generation of technology. I think that would be a mistake, because I think one of the ways weve been able to be so successful in Kosovo and Bosnia and Haiti and in other places is by having the technological edge. You know, we won that conflict in Kosovo without losing a single human life in combat, a single American life in combat. Now, readiness. The trends before we — before I got my current job were on the decline, the number of divisions were reduced. I argued that we should reverse that trend and take it back up. And Im happy to tell you that we have. Now, in my budget for the next ten years I propose $100 billion for this purpose. The governor proposes $45 billion. I propose more than twice as much because I think its needed.

While I acknowledge your points about privacy concerns and the need to safeguard civil liberties, it's crucial to consider the benefits of increased surveillance in preventing and solving crimes. By having robust surveillance systems in place, law enforcement can more effectively track and apprehend criminals, ultimately making communities safer. Additionally, the deterrence effect of knowing that one is being watched can discourage individuals from engaging in illegal activities in the first place. It's about striking a balance between security and privacy to ensure the safety.

The Fat Acceptance Movement is an essential advocacy effort. It isn't about encouraging unhealthy lifestyles, but rather creating a space of inclusivity for all body types. It challenges traditional beauty standards, which can be exclusive and restrictive. This movement is not a campaign for obesity, but a call for acceptance and respect for everyone, no matter their size.

My administration has tripled the amount of money were spending on homeland security to $30 billion a year. My administration worked with the Congress to create the Department of Homeland Security so we could better coordinate our borders and ports. Weve got 1, 000 extra border patrol on the southern border; want 1, 000 on the northern border. Were modernizing our borders. We spent $3. 1 billion for fire and police, $3. 1 billion. Were doing our duty to provide the funding. But the best way to protect this homeland is to stay on the offense. You know, we have to be right 100 percent of the time. And the enemy only has to be right once to hurt us. Theres a lot of good people working hard. And by the way, weve also changed the culture of the FBI to have counterterrorism as its number one priority. Were communicating better. Were going to reform our intelligence services to make sure that we get the best intelligence possible. The Patriot Act is vital — is vital that the Congress renew the Patriot Act which enables our law enforcement to disrupt terror cells. But again, I repeat to my fellow citizens, the best way to protection is to stay on the offense.

I remain cautious about the implications of relying too heavily on technology in the education system. I believe that cultivating critical thinking, creativity, and interpersonal skills should remain at the core of education, and excessive use of technology may not always align with these goals.

While limiting globalization is necessary to protect the US economy and the livelihoods of our citizens, the risks associated with relying too heavily on global markets, such as job displacement and economic instability, outweigh the potential benefits of spreading ethical practices. By prioritizing the stability and prosperity of our own nation, we can better ensure long-term sustainability and resilience in the face of economic challenges.
